          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.\r\n\r\nDetails a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)","url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908","datePublished":"2016-09-27 02:18:45 UTC","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Slideshare","url":"https://www.slideshare.net/"},"encodingFormat":"application/pdf","fileFormat":"pdf","inLanguage":"en","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908"}}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org/","@type":"BreadcrumbList","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Home","item":"https://www.slideshare.net"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"name":"Internet","item":"https://www.slideshare.net/category/internet"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"name":"No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016","item":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908"}]}</script><script>

data-cy="mobile-header-menu" type="button"><span class="Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/hamburger.5a525941.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><dialog id=":R9am:" class="drawer Drawer_root__ob4ZM Drawer_left__hCqwT"><div class="Drawer_content__ye6ZB"></div><button autofocus="" type="button" aria-label="Close" class="CloseButton_root__zu08d" data-cy="close-drawer"><span class="Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/close.393923c4.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button></dialog><a aria-label="SlideShare a Scribd company logo" class="Logo_root__Qba3h" data-cy="slideshare-logo" title="Return to the homepage" href="https://www.slideshare.net/"><img alt="SlideShare a Scribd company Search</span></span></button></form></div><div class="HeaderActions_root__11_ai undefined"></div></header><div class="SlideshowScreen_root__k9j1_ SlideshowScreen_withKeyMoments__RbHLe"><!--$--><div class="metadata Metadata_root__oCstk Metadata_withAuthorInDescriptionOnMobile__NphpB" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><div class="Stats_leftContent__588PR"><time dateTime="2016-09-27 02:18:45 UTC"><span class="skeleton Skeleton_root__U4QqL Skeleton_rounded__BLBq2" style="width:75px;height:24px"></span></time><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_medium__rk8Tn text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0">•</span></div><div class="Stats_rightContent__8d0AF"><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">22 likes</span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_medium__rk8Tn text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0">•</span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">41,946<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5 Metadata_hiddenOnMobile__K4HVV"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-MatthewDunwoody1-48x48.jpg?cb=1474942725" alt="Matthew Dunwoody" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><a class="Link_root__vn3ab Author_link___lVxw ellipsis Link_primary__Iq4CI Link_size-large__W0PAv Link_weight-regular__yPpnB" data-cy="author-link" title="Matthew Dunwoody" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MatthewDunwoody1">Matthew Dunwoody</a><button type="button" class="FollowButton_root__FxpBi Author_follow__Lw4TS FollowButton_follow__d_6u5">Follow</button></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_" data-cy="document-description"><p>Every IR presents unique challenges. But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.

Details a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)<button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_less__BvWbY Description_hidden__a9QZJ" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read less"><span>Read less</span></button></p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more"><span>Read more</span></button></div><div class="actions class="MetadataToolbar_underline__QQn0C"></div></div></div><!--/$--><!--$--><!--/$--><div class="player Player_root__L1AmF"><div id="new-player" class="vertical-player VerticalPlayer_root__K8_YS" data-slideshow-id="66447908"><div><div id="slide1" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-0" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.1
NO EASY BREACH
DERBYCON 2016 #NOEASYBREACH
Matt Dunwoody @matthewdunwoody
Nick Carr @itsreallynick
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="eager" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-1-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-1-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-1-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-1-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide2" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-1" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.2
How It All Started
• 1 average spearphishing email
• 1 failed client remediation
• 1 very determined nation state
• Attacker’s mission not impacted by ongoing remediation
measures
• 2 attacker objectives:
• Steal email of targeted VIPs
• Monitor security team, response &amp; detection efforts
FUN FACT: This was APT29
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-2-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-2-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-2-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-2-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide3" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-2" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.3
Several Months Later…
• The Aftermath
• Four person Mandiant team
• Over 1,039 compromised systems
• Over 1,000 unique malware samples
• Over 1,000 different unique C2 domains / IPs
• Over 50,000 email communications stolen
• Including scripts &amp; tools: 7,000+ attacker files
• How did they pull it off?
• Fast-paced intrusion
• Very stealthy
• Rapidly changing tactics
• Employed advanced attack techniques
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.4
Challenge 1: Fast-Paced Attacker
• Attacker infected 10 systems per day with
primary backdoor family
• Especially when provoked (maintained baseline foothold)
• Accessed hundreds of systems for recon and
credential theft
• Removed tools and forensic artifacts to hide
activity
• Deployed additional backdoor families
• Continued to steal data every week
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.5
Our Response: Triaged Where Possible
• Moved from typical Live Response analysis to
abbreviated triage
• Brief analysis leveraging known attacker TTPs
• Developed indicators to assist triage
• Partially automated the analysis process
• Some activity not unique enough to sig
• Focused on:
• Lateral movement
• Walking back up the chain
• Pivoting, recon, new tools or backdoors
• Signs of data theft
• Deviation from typical attacker activity
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-5-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-5-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-5-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-5-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide6" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-5" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.6
Our Response: Streamlined Documentation
• Typical LR reports and timelines took too much time
• Still needed to document findings
• Compressed notes from systems into brief,
standardized text blocks
• Malware and attacker tools on the system
• Persistence mechanisms
• Periods of attacker activity and significant
timestamps
• Source of activity
• Documented significant findings
• New TTPs
• Data theft
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-6-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-6-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-6-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-6-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide7" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-6" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.7
Lesson Learned: Be Fast and Flexible
• Be willing to change normal practices
and disregard official methodologies
when they’re not working
• Make the most of outside help - accept
the limitations of your circumstances and
do what you can to maximize your
chances of success
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-7-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-7-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-7-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-7-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide8" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-7" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.8
Challenge 2: Stealthy Attacker
• Attacker using counter forensic techniques to hide
endpoint and network activity
• Endpoint: secure deletion, impressive OPSEC (pack up and
move), 90% doctrine
• Network: compromised third party websites &amp; social media
C2, altered communication scheme + strong crypto,
embraced SSL
• The odds were stacked against us
• Unable to use Mandiant network sensors and signatures
• Existing devices inconsistently-deployed and coverage spotty
• “Rolling remediation” actions showed our hand so attacker
knew which evasion tactics were working
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-8-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-8-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-8-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-8-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide9" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-8" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.9
• Attacker considered every detail
• Mass activity to obscure the real target
• More evident in recent campaigns
• Widespread phishing with a prioritized target list
• They might even want the first system to be caught
• Data theft using only legitimate US-based services,
complicating any law enforcement response
• Gmail, Google Drive using APIs
• OneDrive
• Monitored Us
• Targeted the IR operations throughout the compromise
• Were we onto them and how much time did they have left?
BONUS SLIDE: Even More OPSEC
he looks cozy
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-9-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-9-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-9-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-9-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide10" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-9" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.10
Our Response: Found Clues in the Ruble
• Maximized the utility of trace forensic artifacts
• Some attacker behavior recovered from sdelete
• File path regex for artifacts
• Everything from AAA.AAA to ZZZ.ZZZ
• Entry Modified timestamp typically indicated when
sdelete occurred
• EULA Accept registry key for each Sysinternals tool
• Searched for new sdelete usage
• Prefetch entries for some operations (e.g., RAR)
included deleted items in Accessed Files
STEALTHYATTACKER
FUN FACT: Now it’s built-in!
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-10-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-10-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-10-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-10-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide11" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-10" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.11
Our Response: Made the Best of What We Had
• Learned and leveraged client’s network tools
• Embraced the varying technology across
business units
• Took time and patience to filter out the
network noise
• Searched for every new system by timeframe
• Searched activity between sets of infected hosts
• Automated where possible
• Developed dashboards
STEALTHYATTACKER
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-11-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-11-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-11-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-11-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide12" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-11" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.12
Our Response: Made the Best of What We Had
• Found the helpful but forgotten alerts
• SMB transfer of UPX-packed files
• Extracted fields we wanted
• Signature combinations solved mysteries
• Schtasks.exe usage by UUID
• SMB writes to System32
• Network time preserved when other
timestamps could not be trusted
STEALTHYATTACKER
signature=MSRPC_SuspiciousEncryption
event_info=&quot;UUID=86d35949-83c9-4044-b424-
db363231fd0c*”
src_ip=&quot;10.*&quot; dest_ip=&quot;10.*”
( dest_port=49154 OR dest_port=49155
)
FUN FACT: This was our initial
discovery of HAMMERTOSS
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-12-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-12-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-12-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-12-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide13" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-12" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.13
Our Response: Made New Shiny Things
• Deployed additional budget-friendly
open source tech
• Found ways to apply our methodology
• Connected to our incident tracker
• Sparklines for time + volume of activity
• Prioritized host analysis based on traffic
• Smashed and grabbed before the wipe!
STEALTHYATTACKER
host_10

host_5

host_2

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-13-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-13-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-13-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-13-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide14" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-13" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.14
Lesson Learned: Improve Visibility and Don’t Stop Looking
• Map attacker activity to potential data sources and
use everything available to minimize blind spots
• Give your team access to existing tools outside of
their normal process
• Consider deploying additional technology
• Network time provides reliable chronology
despite host-based timestomping
• Combat IR fatigue by automating high-confidence
(and boring stuff)
• Once an attacker is found, fight to maintain line-of-
sight
STEALTHYATTACKER
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-14-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-14-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-14-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-14-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide15" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-14" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.15
Challenge 3: Rapidly-Evolving Tactics
• New and updated backdoors
• 7 distinct backdoor families
• SEADADDY went through 3 version updates
• Seven unique persistence mechanisms
• Registry run key, .LNK files, services, WMI, named scheduled
tasks, hijacking scheduled tasks, over-writing legitimate files
• Cycled persistence techniques regularly
• Minimal re-use of metadata commonly tracked and shared as
indicators
• Malware MD5, file name, file size, and C2 unique to each
system
• Attacker didn’t need to re-use compromised accounts
FUN FACT: On current case,
APT29 used unique UAC
bypass &amp; persistence that was
first posted online days before
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-15-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-15-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-15-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-15-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide16" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-15" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.16
Our Response: Maintained Eye Contact
• Fought to keep network visibility on all malware families
• Backdoor version 1: could see it, sig it, and decode it
PHPSESSID = base64( zlib( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) )
• Backdoor version 2: lost ability to decode it
Cookie{2,7} = customb64( zlib( rc4( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) ) )
• Backdoor version 3: lost ability to sig it
random_split( Cookie{2,7} = customb64( zlib( rc4( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) ) )
• Wrapped in SSL: lost ability to see it
… at first
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
FUN FACT: This was SEADADDY
certificate email SSL cipher start stop
root@domain1.com TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
10/14/15
14:13:00
10/15/15
00:14:37
support@vendor.com TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA
10/14/15
16:13:29
10/14/15
16:13:29
root@domain2.com TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
10/13/15
13:30:17
10/14/15
03:14:04
admin@example.com TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
10/11/15
13:02:21
10/12/15
10:58:59
Finding attacker SSL usage using Bro’s ssl.log
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-16-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-16-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-16-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-16-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide17" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-16" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.17
Our Response: Prioritized the Unknown
• Spent time analyzing systems with unknown activity
• The most interesting systems were the ones
accessed but we didn’t know what they did
• Limited analysis on systems with known and consistent
attacker tactics
• While not useful as standalone indicators, tracked
breach data to prioritize discovered systems
• Identified common forensic artifacts between
systems with shared C2
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-17-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-17-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-17-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-17-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide18" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-17" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.18
Our Response: Continually Improved Indicators
• Created indicators for every stage of attack lifecycle
• All seven persistence mechanisms, recon, lateral movement, and data theft
• Methodology IOCs helped identify systems without known malware
• Reverse engineered every backdoor revision &amp; updated indicators
• Maintained a list of high-confidence indicators to focus new IOC development
• Developed flexible &amp; resilient indicators
• Provided high-fidelity matches across versions, regardless of morphing
• Used imports and exports, size ranges, section names, compile times, and
other consistent attributes
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-18-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-18-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-18-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-18-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide19" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-18" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.19
Our Response: Continually Improved Indicators
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
• Automated analysis of backdoor for
comparison and configuration extraction;
enterprise-wide search of process memory
• Indicators based on packaging and delivery
• Import hashes, size, section names,
artifacts of wrapper execution everywhere
possible
• Adapted file system IOC+regex to
process handles, prefetch, and event
logs
• Identified malware staged for SMB transfer
obfuscated-
backdoor.py
PyInstaller /
Py2Exe
UPX-packed
...transferred
laterally
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-19-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-19-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-19-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-19-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide20" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-19" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.20
Lesson Learned: Find It, Refine It, Re-Find It
• Enhance and test your best indicators even when
they’re working
• Track what the attacker can change before you lose
visibility of their activity
• Don’t let technical data fall through the cracks, even
when visibility is good and the details have marginal
value as indicators
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-20-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-20-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-20-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-20-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide21" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-20" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.21
Challenge 4: Advanced Attack Techniques
• Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)
• Attacker used WMI to persist backdoors
• Embedded backdoor files and PowerShell scripts in WMI repo
• Used WMI to steal credentials from remote systems
• Configured WMI to extract and execute backdoors months in the
future, to evade remediation
• Attacker leveraged PowerShell
• Stealthy backdoors
• PowerShell scripts like Invoke-Mimikatz evaded A/V detection
• Excellent WMI integration
• Kerberos
• Attacker used Kerberos ticket attacks, which made tracking lateral
movement difficult
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-21-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-21-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-21-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-21-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide22" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-21" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.22
Our Response: Tackled Attacker WMI Usage
• Searched for WMI persistence
• Manually parsed from objects.data strings on endpoints
• Ran script across the environment to identify persistence
• Colleagues developed custom MIR audit to allow for sweeping
• Identified evidence of attacker code in WMI repo
• Attacker embedded PowerShell code in WMI class properties to execute on remote system
• Identified class and property names and code in objects.data strings
• Searched contents of CIM repo at scale
• Parsed out embedded scripts and malware
• The repo was a poorly documented, complex structure, so parsing was difficult and manual
• Willi Ballenthin, Matt Graeber and Claudiu Teodorescu made repo parsers (after the
investigation was completed)
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-22-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-22-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-22-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-22-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide23" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-22" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.23
Our Response: Tackled Attacker WMI Usage
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-23-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-23-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-23-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-23-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide24" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-23" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.24
Our Response: Increased PowerShell Visibility
• Upgraded the environment to PowerShell 3.0 and enabled
logging
• Logging captured input/output, variable initialization, etc.
• Captured entire functions of PS scripts, attacker commands, script output,
etc.
• Wrote indicators based on observed attacker activity
• Identified lateral movement, unique backdoors, credential theft, data theft,
recon, persistence creation, etc.
• Turned attacker PowerShell usage from a threat to a benefit
• Logging and IOCs made finding and analyzing attacker activity much easier
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
FUN FACT: There’s now a blog post and
my script block logging parser on GitHub
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-24-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-24-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-24-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-24-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide25" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-24" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.25
Our Response: Increased PowerShell Visibility
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-25-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-25-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-25-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-25-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide26" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-25" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.26
Our Response: Addressed Ticket Attacks
• Worked around Kerberos attacks
• Swept for Invoke-Mimikatz PTT usage in PS logs to identify pivot systems
• Swept for other indicators of lateral movement to identify destination systems
• Looked for remote Kerberos logons around the time of attacker activity
• Developed indicators
• Based on research by Sean Metcalf at adsecurity.org
• Developed late in the investigation
• Extremely high-fidelity
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-26-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-26-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-26-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-26-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide27" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-26" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.27
Our Response: Addressed Ticket Attacks
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
Event ID 4624 Event ID 4672
Event ID 4634
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-27-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-27-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-27-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-27-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide28" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-27" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.28
BONUS SLIDE: Even More WMI + PS
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-28-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-28-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-28-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-28-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide29" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-28" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.29
BONUS SLIDE: Even More WMI + PS
FUN FACT: We saw the attacker test
this backdoor before deployment
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-29-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-29-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-29-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-29-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide30" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-29" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.30
Lesson Learned: Turn Weakness Into Strength
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
• Use attackers’ strengths against them
• Unique attacks make for high-fidelity indicators
• Identify the activity
• Develop indicators
• Increase visibility at scale
• Automate detection
• Create an alerting system, if possible
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-30-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-30-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-30-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-30-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide31" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-30" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.31
• Backdoor used TOR hidden services to provide secure, discrete remote
access
• Used Meek plugin to hide traffic
• Forwarded TOR traffic to ports:
• 3389 – Remote Desktop
• 139 – Netbios
• 445 – SMB
• Modified registry to enable RDP
• “Sticky-keys” to provide unauthenticated, privileged console access
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
FUN FACT: This was first deployed 3 hours before remediation
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-31-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-31-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-31-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-31-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide32" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-31" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.32
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-32-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-32-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-32-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-32-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide33" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-32" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.33
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
Client Endpoint
APT29
(actual image)
TOR network
Meekreflector
.appspot.com
Mail.google.com
Google Cloud
SSL HTTP TOR TOR
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-33-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-33-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-33-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-33-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide34" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-33" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.34
If You’ve Learned Nothing Else Today…
SUPER IMPRESSIVE CONCLUSION SLIDE
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s pace
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s visibility
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s development
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s advanced techniques
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s intensity.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-34-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-34-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-34-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-34-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide35" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-34" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.35
“True happiness incident response is a
life of continual self-improvement.
The greater the struggle, the more
enriching the experience is for your life.”
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-35-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-35-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-35-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-35-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide36" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-35" alt="Copyright © FireEye, Inc. All rights reserved.36
THANK YOU
QUESTIONS?
DERBYCON 2016 #NOEASYBREACH
Matt Dunwoody @matthewdunwoody
Nick Carr @itsreallynick
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-36-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-36-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/75/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-36-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/noeasybreach-derbycon2016-160927021845/85/No-Easy-Breach-DerbyCon-2016-36-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div></div></div></div><!--$--><div class="RelatedContent_root__29Np1"><div class="RelatedContent_wrapper__riU7l"><h2 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h2__f9yvs RelatedContent_title__QUhpL">More Related Content</h2><div></div><div></div><div id="between-recs-ad-1-container" class="freestar-ad-container FreestarAdContainer_root__qPPC_" style="--fallback-aspect-ratio:undefined / undefined"><div><div class="" id="between-recs-ad-1"></div></div></div><div></div><div id="between-recs-ad-2-container" class="freestar-ad-container FreestarAdContainer_root__qPPC_" style="--fallback-aspect-ratio:undefined / undefined"><div><div class="" id="between-recs-ad-2"></div></div></div></div></div><!--/$--><div class="Transcript_root__Vrf6Q"><h2 class="Transcript_title__YgAka"><span class="Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/file.5db1ba24.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span>No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016</h2><div><ul class="Transcript_list__faItj"><div><li>1. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#1">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.1
NO EASY BREACH
DERBYCON 2016 #NOEASYBREACH
Matt Dunwoody @matthewdunwoody
Nick Carr @itsreallynick
 </li></div><div><li>2. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#2">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.2
How It All Started
• 1 average spearphishing email
• 1 failed client remediation
• 1 very determined nation state
• Attacker’s mission not impacted by ongoing remediation
measures
• 2 attacker objectives:
• Steal email of targeted VIPs
• Monitor security team, response &amp; detection efforts
FUN FACT: This was APT29
 </li></div><div><li>3. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#3">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.3
Several Months Later…
• The Aftermath
• Four person Mandiant team
• Over 1,039 compromised systems
• Over 1,000 unique malware samples
• Over 1,000 different unique C2 domains / IPs
• Over 50,000 email communications stolen
• Including scripts &amp; tools: 7,000+ attacker files
• How did they pull it off?
• Fast-paced intrusion
• Very stealthy
• Rapidly changing tactics
• Employed advanced attack techniques
 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#4">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.4
Challenge 1: Fast-Paced Attacker
• Attacker infected 10 systems per day with
primary backdoor family
• Especially when provoked (maintained baseline foothold)
• Accessed hundreds of systems for recon and
credential theft
• Removed tools and forensic artifacts to hide
activity
• Deployed additional backdoor families
• Continued to steal data every week
 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#5">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.5
Our Response: Triaged Where Possible
• Moved from typical Live Response analysis to
abbreviated triage
• Brief analysis leveraging known attacker TTPs
• Developed indicators to assist triage
• Partially automated the analysis process
• Some activity not unique enough to sig
• Focused on:
• Lateral movement
• Walking back up the chain
• Pivoting, recon, new tools or backdoors
• Signs of data theft
• Deviation from typical attacker activity
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 </li></div><div><li>6. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#6">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.6
Our Response: Streamlined Documentation
• Typical LR reports and timelines took too much time
• Still needed to document findings
• Compressed notes from systems into brief,
standardized text blocks
• Malware and attacker tools on the system
• Persistence mechanisms
• Periods of attacker activity and significant
timestamps
• Source of activity
• Documented significant findings
• New TTPs
• Data theft
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 </li></div><div><li>7. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#7">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.7
Lesson Learned: Be Fast and Flexible
• Be willing to change normal practices
and disregard official methodologies
when they’re not working
• Make the most of outside help - accept
the limitations of your circumstances and
do what you can to maximize your
chances of success
FAST-PACED ATTACKER
 </li></div><div><li>8. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#8">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.8
Challenge 2: Stealthy Attacker
• Attacker using counter forensic techniques to hide
endpoint and network activity
• Endpoint: secure deletion, impressive OPSEC (pack up and
move), 90% doctrine
• Network: compromised third party websites &amp; social media
C2, altered communication scheme + strong crypto,
embraced SSL
• The odds were stacked against us
• Unable to use Mandiant network sensors and signatures
• Existing devices inconsistently-deployed and coverage spotty
• “Rolling remediation” actions showed our hand so attacker
knew which evasion tactics were working
 </li></div><div><li>9. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#9">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.9
• Attacker considered every detail
• Mass activity to obscure the real target
• More evident in recent campaigns
• Widespread phishing with a prioritized target list
• They might even want the first system to be caught
• Data theft using only legitimate US-based services,
complicating any law enforcement response
• Gmail, Google Drive using APIs
• OneDrive
• Monitored Us
• Targeted the IR operations throughout the compromise
• Were we onto them and how much time did they have left?
BONUS SLIDE: Even More OPSEC
he looks cozy
 </li></div><div><li>10. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#10">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.10
Our Response: Found Clues in the Ruble
• Maximized the utility of trace forensic artifacts
• Some attacker behavior recovered from sdelete
• File path regex for artifacts
• Everything from AAA.AAA to ZZZ.ZZZ
• Entry Modified timestamp typically indicated when
sdelete occurred
• EULA Accept registry key for each Sysinternals tool
• Searched for new sdelete usage
• Prefetch entries for some operations (e.g., RAR)
included deleted items in Accessed Files
STEALTHYATTACKER
FUN FACT: Now it’s built-in!
 </li></div><div><li>11. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#11">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.11
Our Response: Made the Best of What We Had
• Learned and leveraged client’s network tools
• Embraced the varying technology across
business units
• Took time and patience to filter out the
network noise
• Searched for every new system by timeframe
• Searched activity between sets of infected hosts
• Automated where possible
• Developed dashboards
STEALTHYATTACKER
 </li></div><div><li>12. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#12">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.12
Our Response: Made the Best of What We Had
• Found the helpful but forgotten alerts
• SMB transfer of UPX-packed files
• Extracted fields we wanted
• Signature combinations solved mysteries
• Schtasks.exe usage by UUID
• SMB writes to System32
• Network time preserved when other
timestamps could not be trusted
STEALTHYATTACKER
signature=MSRPC_SuspiciousEncryption
event_info=&quot;UUID=86d35949-83c9-4044-b424-
db363231fd0c*”
src_ip=&quot;10.*&quot; dest_ip=&quot;10.*”
( dest_port=49154 OR dest_port=49155
)
FUN FACT: This was our initial
discovery of HAMMERTOSS
 </li></div><div><li>13. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#13">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.13
Our Response: Made New Shiny Things
• Deployed additional budget-friendly
open source tech
• Found ways to apply our methodology
• Connected to our incident tracker
• Sparklines for time + volume of activity
• Prioritized host analysis based on traffic
• Smashed and grabbed before the wipe!
STEALTHYATTACKER
host_10
host_9
host_8
host_7
host_6
host_5
host_4
host_3
host_2
host_1
 </li></div><div><li>14. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#14">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.14
Lesson Learned: Improve Visibility and Don’t Stop Looking
• Map attacker activity to potential data sources and
use everything available to minimize blind spots
• Give your team access to existing tools outside of
their normal process
• Consider deploying additional technology
• Network time provides reliable chronology
despite host-based timestomping
• Combat IR fatigue by automating high-confidence
(and boring stuff)
• Once an attacker is found, fight to maintain line-of-
sight
STEALTHYATTACKER
 </li></div><div><li>15. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#15">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.15
Challenge 3: Rapidly-Evolving Tactics
• New and updated backdoors
• 7 distinct backdoor families
• SEADADDY went through 3 version updates
• Seven unique persistence mechanisms
• Registry run key, .LNK files, services, WMI, named scheduled
tasks, hijacking scheduled tasks, over-writing legitimate files
• Cycled persistence techniques regularly
• Minimal re-use of metadata commonly tracked and shared as
indicators
• Malware MD5, file name, file size, and C2 unique to each
system
• Attacker didn’t need to re-use compromised accounts
FUN FACT: On current case,
APT29 used unique UAC
bypass &amp; persistence that was
first posted online days before
 </li></div><div><li>16. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#16">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.16
Our Response: Maintained Eye Contact
• Fought to keep network visibility on all malware families
• Backdoor version 1: could see it, sig it, and decode it
PHPSESSID = base64( zlib( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) )
• Backdoor version 2: lost ability to decode it
Cookie{2,7} = customb64( zlib( rc4( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) ) )
• Backdoor version 3: lost ability to sig it
random_split( Cookie{2,7} = customb64( zlib( rc4( aes( BACKDOOR C2 ) ) ) )
• Wrapped in SSL: lost ability to see it
… at first
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
FUN FACT: This was SEADADDY
certificate email SSL cipher start stop
root@domain1.com TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
10/14/15
14:13:00
10/15/15
00:14:37
support@vendor.com TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA
10/14/15
16:13:29
10/14/15
16:13:29
root@domain2.com TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
10/13/15
13:30:17
10/14/15
03:14:04
admin@example.com TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
10/11/15
13:02:21
10/12/15
10:58:59
Finding attacker SSL usage using Bro’s ssl.log
 </li></div><div><li>17. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#17">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.17
Our Response: Prioritized the Unknown
• Spent time analyzing systems with unknown activity
• The most interesting systems were the ones
accessed but we didn’t know what they did
• Limited analysis on systems with known and consistent
attacker tactics
• While not useful as standalone indicators, tracked
breach data to prioritize discovered systems
• Identified common forensic artifacts between
systems with shared C2
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 </li></div><div><li>18. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#18">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.18
Our Response: Continually Improved Indicators
• Created indicators for every stage of attack lifecycle
• All seven persistence mechanisms, recon, lateral movement, and data theft
• Methodology IOCs helped identify systems without known malware
• Reverse engineered every backdoor revision &amp; updated indicators
• Maintained a list of high-confidence indicators to focus new IOC development
• Developed flexible &amp; resilient indicators
• Provided high-fidelity matches across versions, regardless of morphing
• Used imports and exports, size ranges, section names, compile times, and
other consistent attributes
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 </li></div><div><li>19. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#19">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.19
Our Response: Continually Improved Indicators
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
• Automated analysis of backdoor for
comparison and configuration extraction;
enterprise-wide search of process memory
• Indicators based on packaging and delivery
• Import hashes, size, section names,
artifacts of wrapper execution everywhere
possible
• Adapted file system IOC+regex to
process handles, prefetch, and event
logs
• Identified malware staged for SMB transfer
obfuscated-
backdoor.py
PyInstaller /
Py2Exe
UPX-packed
...transferred
laterally
 </li></div><div><li>20. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#20">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.20
Lesson Learned: Find It, Refine It, Re-Find It
• Enhance and test your best indicators even when
they’re working
• Track what the attacker can change before you lose
visibility of their activity
• Don’t let technical data fall through the cracks, even
when visibility is good and the details have marginal
value as indicators
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
 </li></div><div><li>21. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#21">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.21
Challenge 4: Advanced Attack Techniques
• Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)
• Attacker used WMI to persist backdoors
• Embedded backdoor files and PowerShell scripts in WMI repo
• Used WMI to steal credentials from remote systems
• Configured WMI to extract and execute backdoors months in the
future, to evade remediation
• Attacker leveraged PowerShell
• Stealthy backdoors
• PowerShell scripts like Invoke-Mimikatz evaded A/V detection
• Excellent WMI integration
• Kerberos
• Attacker used Kerberos ticket attacks, which made tracking lateral
movement difficult
 </li></div><div><li>22. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#22">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.22
Our Response: Tackled Attacker WMI Usage
• Searched for WMI persistence
• Manually parsed from objects.data strings on endpoints
• Ran script across the environment to identify persistence
• Colleagues developed custom MIR audit to allow for sweeping
• Identified evidence of attacker code in WMI repo
• Attacker embedded PowerShell code in WMI class properties to execute on remote system
• Identified class and property names and code in objects.data strings
• Searched contents of CIM repo at scale
• Parsed out embedded scripts and malware
• The repo was a poorly documented, complex structure, so parsing was difficult and manual
• Willi Ballenthin, Matt Graeber and Claudiu Teodorescu made repo parsers (after the
investigation was completed)
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 </li></div><div><li>23. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#23">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.23
Our Response: Tackled Attacker WMI Usage
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 </li></div><div><li>24. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#24">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.24
Our Response: Increased PowerShell Visibility
• Upgraded the environment to PowerShell 3.0 and enabled
logging
• Logging captured input/output, variable initialization, etc.
• Captured entire functions of PS scripts, attacker commands, script output,
etc.
• Wrote indicators based on observed attacker activity
• Identified lateral movement, unique backdoors, credential theft, data theft,
recon, persistence creation, etc.
• Turned attacker PowerShell usage from a threat to a benefit
• Logging and IOCs made finding and analyzing attacker activity much easier
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
FUN FACT: There’s now a blog post and
my script block logging parser on GitHub
 </li></div><div><li>25. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#25">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.25
Our Response: Increased PowerShell Visibility
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 </li></div><div><li>26. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#26">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.26
Our Response: Addressed Ticket Attacks
• Worked around Kerberos attacks
• Swept for Invoke-Mimikatz PTT usage in PS logs to identify pivot systems
• Swept for other indicators of lateral movement to identify destination systems
• Looked for remote Kerberos logons around the time of attacker activity
• Developed indicators
• Based on research by Sean Metcalf at adsecurity.org
• Developed late in the investigation
• Extremely high-fidelity
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
 </li></div><div><li>27. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#27">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.27
Our Response: Addressed Ticket Attacks
ADVANCED ATTACK TECHNIQUES
Event ID 4624 Event ID 4672
Event ID 4634
 </li></div><div><li>28. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#28">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.28
BONUS SLIDE: Even More WMI + PS
 </li></div><div><li>29. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#29">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.29
BONUS SLIDE: Even More WMI + PS
FUN FACT: We saw the attacker test
this backdoor before deployment
 </li></div><div><li>30. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#30">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.30
Lesson Learned: Turn Weakness Into Strength
RAPIDLY-EVOLVING TACTICS
• Use attackers’ strengths against them
• Unique attacks make for high-fidelity indicators
• Identify the activity
• Develop indicators
• Increase visibility at scale
• Automate detection
• Create an alerting system, if possible
 </li></div><div><li>31. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#31">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.31
• Backdoor used TOR hidden services to provide secure, discrete remote
access
• Used Meek plugin to hide traffic
• Forwarded TOR traffic to ports:
• 3389 – Remote Desktop
• 139 – Netbios
• 445 – SMB
• Modified registry to enable RDP
• “Sticky-keys” to provide unauthenticated, privileged console access
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
FUN FACT: This was first deployed 3 hours before remediation
 </li></div><div><li>32. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#32">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.32
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
 </li></div><div><li>33. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#33">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.33
BONUS SLIDE: TOR backdoor (just because it’s cool)
Client Endpoint
APT29
(actual image)
TOR network
Meekreflector
.appspot.com
Mail.google.com
Google Cloud
SSL HTTP TOR TOR
 </li></div><div><li>34. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#34">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.34
If You’ve Learned Nothing Else Today…
SUPER IMPRESSIVE CONCLUSION SLIDE
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s pace
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s visibility
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s development
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s advanced techniques
• You must match or exceed the attacker’s intensity.
 </li></div><div><li>35. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#35">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.35
“True happiness incident response is a
life of continual self-improvement.
The greater the struggle, the more
enriching the experience is for your life.”
 </li></div><div><li>36. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908#36">Copyright © FireEye, </a> Inc. All rights reserved.36
THANK YOU
QUESTIONS?
DERBYCON 2016 #NOEASYBREACH
Matt Dunwoody @matthewdunwoody
Nick Carr @itsreallynick

type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"name":"slideshow","edgeTestAssignments":[{"name":"example","variant":"A"},{"name":"fullscreen_view","variant":"A"},{"name":"gallery_view","variant":"B"},{"name":"nextjs_profile","variant":"A"},{"name":"reading_modes","variant":"A"},{"name":"recs_placement","variant":"A"},{"name":"recs_placement_v2","variant":"A"}],"layout":{"currentUser":null,"fullPath":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908","osanoId":"079b27eb-bb3f-48dd-9bd9-3feb8aec3c38","featureFlags":[{"name":"disable_facebook","enabled":true},{"name":"document_interstitials_flag","enabled":true},{"name":"recommendation_impression_tracking","enabled":true},{"name":"search_results_tracking","enabled":true},{"name":"view_restriction_without_subscription_after_five","enabled":true},{"name":"disable_lazy_hydration","enabled":false}]},"countryCodeFromFastly":"BR","slideshow":{"username":"MatthewDunwoody1","allowDownloads":true,"allowDownloadOriginalFile":true,"allowEmbeds":true,"canonicalUrl":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908","categories":[{"id":"32","name":"Internet","url":"internet"}],"createdAt":"2016-09-27 02:18:45 UTC","description":"Every IR presents unique challenges. But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.\r\n\r\nDetails a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)","downloadKey":"f18f4c29d69b3e7f4fdc2a5731f078d6d5557d99af7eac8c4f732f8dd0620c85","editorsNotes":[],"emailShareUrl":"mailto:?subject=Check out this SlideShare presentation\u0026body=https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/no-easy-breach-derby-con-2016/66447908","extension":"pdf","facebookShareUrl":"https://facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.slideshare.net%2Fslideshow%2Fno-easy-breach-derby-con-2016%2F66447908\u0026t=No+Easy+Breach+DerbyCon+2016","genaiDescriptionCreatedAt":null,"genaiTest":"control","id":"66447908","iframeEmbed":{"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/8RHRCEd9P1SgJW","height":486,"width":597},"isIndexable":true,"isLikedByCurrentUser":false,"isPrivate":false,"isViewable":true,"language":"en","likes":22,"linkedinShareUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/cws/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.slideshare.net%2Fslideshow%2Fno-easy-breach-derby-con-2016%2F66447908\u0026trk=SLIDESHARE","recommendationsByLocation":{"rightRail":[{"algorithmId":"5","displayTitle":"PHDays 2018 Threat Hunting Hands-On Lab","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":116,"score":0.766673,"slideshowId":"97951462","sourceName":"cm_interact","strippedTitle":"phdays-2018-threat-hunting-handson-lab-97951462","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/phdays2018-180521214400-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"My slides for PHDays 2018 Threat Hunting Hands-On Lab - SAST tools have gotten a reputation for being slow, error-prone, and difficult to use; and out of the box, many of them are – but with a little more knowledge behind how these tools are designed, a SAST tool can be a valuable part of any security program. \r\n\r\nIn this talk, we’ll help you understand the strengths and weaknesses of SAST tools by illustrating how they trace your code for vulnerabilities. You’ll see out-of-the-box rules for commercial and open-source SAST tools, and learn how to write custom rules for the widely-used open source SAST tool, PMD. We’ll explain the value of customizing tools for your organization; and you’ll learn how to integrate SAST technologies into your existing build and deployment pipelines.
